link:labelLink.link:label: Other Accounting And Financial Disclosures
Is the entity in which the reporting party has invested adequately capitalised on a stand alone basis as at the relevant date?

A choice of TRUE/FALSE values TRUE = the entity in which the reporting party has invested is adequately capitalised on a stand alone basis FALSE = the entity in which the reporting party has invested is not adequately capitalised on a stand alone basis
Financial Risk Adequate Capital Indicator
This is the GRF450 L2 region that most appropriately reflects, as at the relevant date, the location of the majority of assets and liabilities of the entity in which the reporting party has invested.
Financial Risk Asset Liability Region GRF450G Code
This is the GRF450 L1 region that most appropriately reflects, as at the relevant date, the location of the majority of assets and liabilities of the entity in which the reporting party has invested.
Financial Risk Asset Liability Region GRF450L Code
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the reporting party's capital base.
Financial Risk Capital Base Amount

This is the value. as at the relevant date, of the reporting party's capital coverage surplus or deficit.
The capital coverage surplus or deficit represents the adequacy of an entity's current capital resources in meeting the current and future needs of the entity. Adequacy will generally be reflected in the extent of surplus capital when capital levels are considered with respect to capital adequacy requirements as determined in accordance to relevant prudential standards.
Financial Risk Capital Coverage Surplus Or Deficit Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of capitalised loan and lease origination fees and commissions paid to mortgage originators and brokers.
Loan/lease origination/broker fees and commissions that are capitalised as an asset are to be set off against the balance of upfront loan/lease fees associated with the lending portfolios that are treated as deferred income and recognised as a liability.
Where the net amount for loan/lease origination fees and commissions:
(a) has a positive balance, this item must be reported as a positive figure.
(b) has a negative balance, provided the deferred income satisfies the criteria set out in APS 111, this item may be reported as a negative figure. Where the criteria are not satisfied, this item must be reported as zero.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Financial Risk Capitalised Loan Lease Origination Fees Commissions Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the net position/gap in cash flows due to interest rate repricing.
This amount represents the sum of all relevant cash flows (inflows and outflows), resulting in a single positive or negative cash flow amount. This intends to illustrate the difference in timing between interest rate repricing of assets and liabilities, measuring the sensitivity of earnings to changes in interest rates at varying durations.
Financial Risk Cash Flows Net Position Gap Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date of the amount calculated in accordance with the relevant prudential standards, by which the exposure to a counterparty (or group of related counterparties) exceeds the threshold set out in the relevant prudential standard.
Financial Risk Concentration Excess Over Threshold Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date of the concentration risk capital charge calculated as A + B, where
A = Maximum Event Retention, being the largest loss to which an insurer will be exposed (taking into account the probability of that loss) due to concentration of risk exposures, after netting out any potential reinsurance recoverables;
B = the cost of one reinstatement of the catastrophe reinsurance cover in cases where the reinsurance cover has not been pre-paid by the insurer.
Concentration risk capital charge is the component of the minimum capital requirement that takes into account the highest aggregation of risks of an insurer and is determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Financial Risk Concentration Risk Capital Charge Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the cost of one full reinstatement premium for the insurer's catastrophe cover as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Following a loss occurrence recoverable under a catastrophe excess of loss reinsurance program, the cost of one reinstatement is the contracted premium payable by the insurer to fully reinstate the reinsurance program to its original level existing prior to the occurrence of that loss.
For prudential purposes, the loss occurrence is considered to be the probable maximum loss event eroding one total loss from the entire catastrophe excess of loss reinsurance program. The cost of one reinstatement is the contracted premium of reinstating the entire catastrophe excess of loss reinsurance program.
Financial Risk Cost Of One Reinstatement Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the net exposures to listed equities less derivatives over listed equities (where the derivative exposure for options is calculated on a delta-weighted basis).
Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve: - Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or - Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value. The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).
Delta-weighted position is calculated by multiplying the market value of the underlying position by the absolute value of the delta on that position. Delta represents the rate of change of an options price for a unit change in the price of the underlying asset.
Financial Risk Exposure Listed Equities Net Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all exposures regardless of whether it has been recognised on or off-balance sheet.
The value of this item is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Exposures Amount
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all exposures regardless of whether it has been recognised on or off-balance sheet.
Financial Risk Exposures Accounting Amount
Financial Risk Exposures Capital Base APS 221 Percent

This is the credit equivalent amount, as at the relevant date, of market-related off-balance sheet exposures, as determined in accordance with Prudential Standard APS 221.
This includes all exposures arising from off-balance sheet market related contracts and is to be reported on a net basis, meaning net of the following exposures: - exposures to the extent that they are secured by cash deposits (subject to satisfying the criteria set out in Prudential Standard APS 112; - exposures to the extent that they are guaranteed by, or secured against securities issued by, governments or central banks (subject to satisfying the conditions set out in APS 112); - exposures arising in the course of settlement of market-related contracts; and - exposures to the extent that they have been written off or specifically provided for.
Netting by novation and close-out netting are permissible for market related contracts provided all the requirements set out in the prudential standards for bilateral netting are met. Multilateral netting and netting of exposures against offsetting positions held by a group of related counterparties are not recognised.
Off-balance sheet refers to assets or liabilities that are not recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting party because they do not satisfy the asset or liability accounting recognition requirements
Financial Risk Exposures Off Balance Sheet Market Related Net Amount
Financial Risk Exposures Off Balance Sheet Market Related Net APS 221 Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of non-market-related off-balance sheet exposures, as determined in accordance with Prudential Standard APS 221.
This includes all contingencies and commitments, whether revocable or not, which have been advised to the counterparty. Any potential chargeback exposures to the counterparty arising from credit card acquiring activities should also be included. Exclude internal limits that have not been formally advised to the counterparty or group of related counterparties and may be cancelled at the reporting party's discretion.
The value of all unused commitments to a counterparty is to be reported on a net basis, meaning net of the following exposures: - exposures to the extent that they are secured by cash deposits (subject to satisfying the criteria in APS 112); - exposures to the extent that they are guaranteed by, or secured against securities issued by, governments or central banks (subject to satisfying the conditions in APS 112); - exposures arising in the course of settlement of market-related contracts; and - exposures to the extent that they have been written off or specifically provided for.
Exposures arising from repos (i.e. sale and repurchase agreements) and reverse repos (i.e. purchase and resale agreements) of securities should be reported as exposures to the issuer of the securities and collateralised loans to the counterparty respectively.
Off-balance sheet refers to assets or liabilities that are not recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting party because they do not satisfy the asset or liability accounting recognition requirements.
Financial Risk Exposures Off Balance Sheet Non Market Related Net Amount
Financial Risk Exposures Off Balance Sheet Non Market Related Net APS 221 Amount
Financial Risk Exposures On Balance Sheet Excluding Loans And Advances Net APS 221 Amount

This is the book value, as at the relevant date, of on-balance sheet exposures, as determined in accordance with Prudential Standard APS 221.
This includes all loans and advances, holding of debt and equity securities, and all other claims on counterparties. Any accrued income associated with the exposure should also be included (e.g. interest, dividends).
This item is to be reported on a net basis, meaning net of the following: - exposures to the extent that they are secured by cash deposits (subject to satisfying the criteria in APS 112); - exposures to the extent that they are guaranteed by, or secured against securities issued by, governments or central banks (subject to satisfying the conditions in APS 112); - exposures arising in the course of settlement of market-related contracts; and - exposures to the extent that they have been written off or specifically provided for.
On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting party, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
Financial Risk Exposures On Balance Sheet Net Amount
Financial Risk Exposures On Balance Sheet Net APS 221 Amount
Financial Risk Exposures On Balance Sheet Other ARF 222 0 Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of total on and off balance sheet exposures as required to be reported on form ARF_222_0.
This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Financial Risk Exposures Total ARF 222 0 Amount

This is the percentage, as at the relevant date, of the value of total exposures as required to be reported on form ARF_222_0, divided by the value of the reporting party's capital base, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
This item is to be reported as a percentage figure.
Financial Risk Exposures Total ARF 222 0 Capital Base Percent

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of total on and off-balance sheets exposures, as determined in accordance with Prudential Standard APS 221.
Total on and off-balance sheet exposures is calculated as the sum of the following amounts: - On-balance sheet exposures, including all loans and advances, holding of debt and equity securities, and all other counterparty claims. Any accrued income associated with the exposure should also be included (e.g. interest, dividends); - Non-market-related off-balance sheet exposures, including all contingencies and commitments, whether revocable or not, which have been advised to the counterparty. Any potential chargeback exposures to the counterparty arising from credit card acquiring activities should also be included. Exclude internal limits that have not been formally advised to the counterparty or group of related counterparties and may be cancelled at the reporting party's discretion; and - Market-related off-balance sheet exposures, including foreign exchange and interest rate derivative contracts etc.
This item is to be reported on a net basis, meaning net of the following exposures: - exposures to the extent that they are secured by cash deposits (subject to satisfying the criteria in APS 112); - exposures to the extent that they are guaranteed by, or secured against securities issued by, governments or central banks (subject to satisfying the conditions in APS 112); - exposures arising in the course of settlement of market-related contracts; and - exposures to the extent that they have been written off or specifically provided for.
On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting party, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
Off-balance sheet refers to assets or liabilities that are not recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting party because they do not satisfy the asset or liability accounting recognition requirements.
Financial Risk Exposures Total Net Amount
Financial Risk Exposures Total Net APS 221 Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the intangible component of investments in non-consolidated subsidiaries arising on acquisition, net of amortisation and impairment.
Intangible assets are defined in accordance with Accounting Standards, but also include any other assets designated as intangible under Prudential Standard APS 111.
Financial Risk Intangible Assets in Non Consolidated Subsidiaries APS 111 Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the interest rate sensitivity calculated on all relevant positions.
This item represents the net position/gap in the cashflows of each position due to interest rate repricing multiplied by the relevant weighting factor. Each resulting weighted position is added together to determine the net (positive or negative) weighting of all relevant positions. This provides an estimate of the sensitivity of earnings to changes in interest rates at varying durations.
Financial Risk Interest Rate Sensitivity Amount
This is the investment capital factor associated with the reported data as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

The enumerated values are: 0 (Zero) = no risk charge applicable 1 = investment capital factor is 1% 2 = investment capital factor is 2% 3 = investment capital factor is 3% 4 = investment capital factor is 4% 5 = investment capital factor is 5% 6 = investment capital factor is 6% 7 = investment capital factor is 7% 8 = investment capital factor is 8%
Financial Risk Investment Capital Factor Code

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the Maximum Event Retention (MER) calculated. This represents the Probable Maximum Loss (PML) plus claims handling expenses calculated, and net of allowable reinsurance. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Probable Maximum Loss (PML) is the largest gross loss to which an insurer will be exposed (taking into account the probability of that loss) due to a concentration of risk exposures, without any allowance for potential reinsurance recoveries.
Financial Risk Maximum Event Retention Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the minimum capital requirement, being the amount of risk-based capital that is required for an entity to hold to meet its obligations under a wide range of circumstances determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Financial Risk Minimum Capital Requirement Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the adjustments made to the Probable Maximum Loss (PML) for the reporting party, as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
This item is reported to reflect a decrease in the sum insured and therefore PML as a result of the expiration of existing policies.
Probable Maximum Loss (PML) is the largest gross loss to which an insurer will be exposed (within the realms of possibility) due to a concentration of risk exposures, without any allowance for potential reinsurance assets.
Financial Risk Mortgages Adjustment To Probable Maximum Loss Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of allowable reinsurance on the Probable Maximum Loss (PML) for the reporting party, as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
This represents the lesser of available reinsurance and 60 per cent of the adjusted PML.
Probable Maximum Loss (PML) is the largest gross loss to which an insurer will be exposed (within the realms of possibility) due to a concentration of risk exposures, without any allowance for potential reinsurance assets.
Financial Risk Mortgages Allowable Reinsurance On Probable Maximum Loss Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of available reinsurance on the Probable Maximum Loss (PML) for the reporting party, as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Probable Maximum Loss (PML) is the largest gross loss to which an insurer will be exposed (within the realms of possibility) due to a concentration of risk exposures, without any allowance for potential reinsurance assets.
Financial Risk Mortgages Available Reinsurance On Probable Maximum Loss Amount

This is the percentage, as at the relevant date, of insurance policies, by value, written under open policy.
Open policy represents a legal arrangement whereby a lender is given direct underwriting control for mortgage insurance policies without reference to the insurer, subject to the transaction meeting certain underwriting requirements.
Financial Risk Mortgages Insured Open Policy Percent

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claims handling expenses on Probable Maximum Loss (PML) for the reporting party, net of allowable reinsurance, as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Claims handling expenses is calculated as five per cent of the adjusted PML for the mortgages insured by the reporting party.
Probable Maximum Loss (PML) is the largest gross loss to which an insurer will be exposed (within the realms of possibility) due to a concentration of risk exposures, without any allowance for potential reinsurance assets.
Financial Risk Mortgages Probable Maximum Loss Claims Handling Expenses Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the on the Probable Maximum Loss (PML) for the reporting party, net of allowable reinsurance amount, as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Probable Maximum Loss (PML) is the largest gross loss to which an insurer will be exposed (within the realms of possibility) due to a concentration of risk exposures, without any allowance for potential reinsurance assets.
Financial Risk Mortgages Probable Maximum Loss Net Of Allowable Reinsurance Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the sum of mortgages insured by the reporting party, as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
The sum insured represents the original exposure amount as stated in the mortgage insurance policy.
Financial Risk Mortgages Sum Insured Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of off-balance sheet exposures.
An off-balance sheet exposure are those that have not been recorded on the balance sheet of the reporting party.
The value of this item is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Off Balance Sheet Exposures Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of off-balance sheet exposures.
An off-balance sheet exposure are those that have not been recorded on the balance sheet of the reporting party.
Financial Risk Off Balance Sheet Exposures Accounting Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all on-balance sheet exposures. Any accrued interest associated with the exposure should also be included.
This item is to be reported net of the following on-balance sheet exposures: - Exposures to the extent that they are secured by cash deposits (subject to satisfying criteria set out in APS 112); - Exposures to the extent that they are guaranteed by governments, or secured by government securities (subject to satisfying criteria set out in APS 110); - Exposures arising in the course of settlement of market-related contracts; and - Exposures to the extent that they have been written off or specifically provided for.
This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Exposures represent the aggregate of all claims, commitments and contingent liabilities arising from on- and off- balance sheet transactions with the entity. This includes equity investments in the entity.
On-balance sheet exposures refer to items of assets that are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position.
Financial Risk On Balance Sheet Exposures Total ARF 222 0 Amount
Financial Risk On Balance Sheet Loans And Advances Net APS 221 Amount

This is the probability of sufficiency used when calculating the net outstanding claims liabilities for the purposes of the statement of financial position.
The probability of sufficiency is the probability that an estimated provision will prove to be sufficient for the purpose for which it was created.
Financial Risk Probability Of Sufficiency Percent

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the following securitisation related items:
- gain-on-sale, including expected future income from a securitisation exposure that the reporting party reports as an on-balance sheet asset or profit, until irrevocably received;
- funds provided by the reporting party to establish a spread, reserve or similar account, until the funds are irrevocably paid to the reporting party;
- the difference between the book value and the amount received by the reporting party, where the originating entity transfers exposures to an SPV below their book value, unless it is written off in the reporting party's profit and loss (and capital) accounts; and
- any other specific deductions in accordance with Prudential Standard APS120.
This item excludes start-up and other establishment costs capitalised.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Securitisation Costs Excluding Start Up And Establishment Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of solvency coverage ratio, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Solvency refers to the ability of an entity to meet its obligations (liabilities) under all contracts at any time.
Financial Risk Solvency Coverage Ratio Fraction

This is the value of the Basel II transitional floor adjusted risk weighted exposure of the reporting party determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards.
The transitional floor adjusted RWA amount is used to calculate the reporting party's actual risk-based capital ratio and assess whether the entity is meeting its prudential capital ratio.
Financial Risk Transitional Floor Adjusted Exposure Amount
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of variations in capital charges as approved by APRA.
Financial Risk Variation In Capital Charges Approved By APRA Amount
This is the description, as at the relevant date, of the detailed line item comprising the variations in capital charges as approved by APRA.
Financial Risk Variation In Capital Charges Approved By APRA Description
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of variations in deduction as approved by APRA.
Financial Risk Variation In Deduction Approved By APRA Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all other Tier 1 capital adequacy deductions as advised by APRA.
This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy APRA Advised Other Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any other adjustments to capital, as required by APRA.
Only report 50% of the resulting amount at this item.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy APRA Other Capital Adjustments 50 Percent Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of applicable assets to be reported on the APRA form GRF_110_0_G 'Capital Adequacy'. This includes assets listed under APRA form GRF_300_0_G Statement of Financial Position. This excludes derivatives and other assets that are subject to a risk charge under the APRA forms GRF_141_0_G and GRF_301_0_G.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Assets GRF 110 G Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the reporting party's capital base, representing the sum of total Tier 1 capital and Tier 2 capital, net of any deductions from capital.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Capital Base Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of capitalised costs associated with debt raisings and other similar transaction-related costs.
The balance of any transaction costs and like items that are capitalised and deferred as an asset must be netted off against the balance of any income deferred as a liability relating to the products giving rise to the capitalised transaction costs (i.e. only deferred costs and income in particular product portfolios may be netted).
Any positive net balance of capitalised transaction costs must be reported as a positive figure. Any surplus of up-front fee income received over deferred costs may be reported as a negative figure where the up-front fee income received satisfies the criteria set in Prudential Standard APS 111. Otherwise, report this item as zero.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Capitalised Debt Raising Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of capitalised information technology software costs, capitalised in accordance with accounting standards.
The balance of any transaction costs and like items that are capitalised and deferred as an asset must be netted off against the balance of any income deferred as a liability relating to the products giving rise to the capitalised transaction costs (i.e. only deferred costs and income in particular product portfolios may be netted).
Any positive net balance of capitalised transaction costs must be reported as a positive figure. Any surplus of up-front fee income received over deferred costs may be reported as a negative figure provided the up-front fee income received satisfies the criteria set under Prudential Standard APS 111. Otherwise, report this item as zero.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with the relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Capitalised Information Technology Software Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of capitalised costs associated with issuing capital instruments.
The balance of any transaction costs and like items that are capitalised and deferred as an asset must be netted off against the balance of any income deferred as a liability relating to the products giving rise to the capitalised transaction costs (i.e. only deferred costs and income in particular product portfolios may be netted).
Any positive net balance of capitalised transaction costs must be reported as a positive figure. Any surplus of up-front fee income received over deferred costs may be reported as a negative figure provided the up-front fee income received satisfies the criteria set in the Prudential Standard APS 111. Otherwise, report this item as zero.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Capitalised Issuing Capital Instruments Amount

This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of capitalised expenses other than those already listed on ARF_110_0_1 and ARF_110_0_2 (where applicable). This includes capitalised expenses of a general nature, such as strategic business development initiatives, and other forms of transaction costs and like costs that are required to be deferred/capitalised and amortised in accordance with accounting standards.
This item is reported as a deduction from Tier 1 capital for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with the Banking Act 1959, relevant Prudential Standards and associated Guidance Notes.
The balance of any transaction costs and like items that are capitalised and deferred as an asset must be netted off against the balance of any income deferred as a liability relating to the products giving rise to the capitalised transaction costs (i.e. only deferred costs and income in particular product portfolios may be netted).
Any positive net balance of capitalised transaction costs must be deducted from Tier 1 capital in accordance with the relevant Prudential Standard. Any surplus of up-front fee income received over deferred costs may be added to Tier 1 capital provided the up-front fee income received satisfies the criteria set under Prudential Standard APS 111. Otherwise, up-front fee income received must not be added to capital.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Capitalised Other ARF 110 0 1 And ARF 110 0 2 Amount

This is, as at the relevant date, the total capital requirement applicable to all positions. This represents the capital requirements on positions giving rise to credit risk, operational risk, market risk, as well as any other capital requirements as imposed by APRA.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Capital Requirement Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all capital adequacy deductions that are required to be made 50 per cent from Tier 1 capital and 50 per cent from Tier 2 capital (i.e. 50/50 capital adequacy deductions). For the purposes of this item only report 50 per cent of the amount of the full deduction.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Deductions Fifty Percent Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the aggregate deficits in employer-sponsored defined benefit superannuation plans, net of deferred tax assets (DTA).
Report this item for superannuation funds as follows, where applicable: - At Level 1, in any of the reporting party's employer-sponsored defined benefit superannuation funds; or - At Level 2, in any of the reporting party's or other Level 2 group member's employer-sponsored defined benefit superannuation funds.
For the purposes of this item, only include deficits to the extent not already reflected in Gross Tier 1 capital. Surpluses and deficits must not be netted across employer-sponsored defined benefit superannuation plans.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Employer Sponsored Defined Benefit Plans Deficit Net Deferred Tax Assets Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the aggregate surpluses in employer-sponsored defined benefit superannuation plans, net of deferred tax liabilities (DTL).
Report this item for superannuation funds as follows, where applicable: - At Level 1, in any of the reporting party's employer-sponsored defined benefit superannuation funds; or - At Level 2, in any of the reporting party's or other Level 2 group member's employer-sponsored defined benefit superannuation funds.
Surpluses and deficits must not be netted across employer-sponsored defined benefit superannuation plans.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Employer Sponsored Defined Benefit Plans Surplus Net Deferred Tax Liabilities Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of equity exposures and other capital investments held by the reporting party.
Where a facility, including a guarantee, provided to a related party or a non-related party constitutes 'capital support', it must be treated as 'other capital investments'.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Equity Exposures And Capital Investments Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of equity exposures and other capital investments held by the reporting party, after deducting the intangible component of the investments where applicable.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Equity Exposures and Capital Investments After Deducting Intangible Assets Fifty Per Cent Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of equity exposures and other capital investments held by the reporting party.
For the purposes of this item, exclude equity exposures and other capital investments where:
(a) the equity exposure or other capital investment is held for trading purposes, in which case it is to be included in the reporting party's risk weighted assets (RWA). (b) the equity exposure is acquired through underwriting of a new equity instrument and the equity instrument is disposed of within 90 days of the date of issue. If the equity instrument is not disposed of within 90 days of issuance, it must be deducted in accordance with the relevant limits for equity exposures and other capital investments, unless the position forms part of the reporting party's trading book; or (c) the equity exposure or other capital investment is held under a legal agreement on behalf of: (i) at Level 1 - an external third party, even if held in the name of the reporting party; or (ii) at Level 2 - a party outside the Level 2 consolidated group, even if held in the name of the reporting party (or another member of its Level 2 consolidated group.).
Where a facility, including a guarantee, provided to a related party or a non-related party constitutes 'capital support', it must be treated as 'other capital investments'.
This item represents a 50/50 capital adequacy deduction, therefore only report 50 per cent of the asset amount at this item. This amount is to be deducted from both Tier 1 and Tier 2 capital.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Equity Exposures And Capital Investments Fifty Per Cent Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any excess amounts of Tier 1 capital instruments ineligible for inclusion in Tier 1 capital due to the limits prescribed under relevant prudential standards, and which is now classed as Upper Tier 2 capital.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Excess Tier 1 Capital Instruments Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of General Reserve for Credit Losses (GRCL), net of tax, determined using the standardised approach to credit risk. Any deferred tax assets (DTA) associated with the collective provisions eligible to be included in the GRCL must be removed.
The amount reported at this item must be limited to 1.25% of Risk Weighted Assets.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy General Reserve For Credit Losses Net Deferred Tax Assets Standardised Approach Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of surplus provisions on non-defaulted exposures, determined using the internal ratings based (IRB) approach to credit risk. This amount is to be reported net of deferred tax assets associated with eligible collective provisions, and is limited to 0.6% of credit risk weighted assets (RWA) of the reporting party.
For non-defaulted exposures, when there is a surplus of total eligible provisions over the total expected loss (EL) amount, the difference is reported at this item (to a maximum of 0.6% of credit RWA) where the surplus provisions are eligible to be treated as General Reserve for Credit Losses (GRCL).
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy General Reserve For Credit Losses Surplus Provisions Non Defaulted Exposures Net Deferred Tax Assets Internal Ratings Based Approach Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of General Reserves, as determined in accordance with Prudential Standard APS 111.
General reserves are created from the appropriation of profits by an entity (or the group of entities) after the payment of all dividends and tax. These may include:
(a) reserves representing the offset to a charge to profit and loss of the entity arising from equity-settled share-based payments (i.e. shares and/or share options) granted to employees as part of their remuneration package (including any shares or share options granted to employees by way of bonus arrangements associated with their employment, and shares or share options granted to employees of an acquired institution in return for continued services). This is provided that: (i) the shares or share options granted relate only to the ordinary shares of the entity itself; and (ii) there are no circumstances in which such remuneration (including bonuses) can be realised, in part or full, other than by way of the issue of ordinary shares of the entity i.e. there is no right for remuneration to be converted to a payment in another form (e.g. cash).
All other reserves associated with share-based payments (refer to Australian accounting standard AASB 2 Share-based Payment) must be excluded from this item; and
(b) cumulative unrealised gains or losses on hedges that offset gains or losses on reserves included in Tier 1 capital (e.g. movements in the currency value of foreign-currency-denominated hedging instruments which offset movements in foreign-currency-denominated items recognised in the foreign currency translation reserve). This includes fair value gains or losses on derivatives representing effective economic hedges of assets.
Exclude General Reserves for Credit Losses from this item.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy General Reserves Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of guarantees and credit derivatives that provide for a materiality threshold and where the is an equivalent to retained first loss positions.
Equivalents to retained first loss positions arise: (a) where credit protection provides for a materiality threshold on payments below which no payment will be made in the event of loss.; and (b) in the context of securitisation, where there is partial coverage of an underlying exposure by a credit derivative, there is a difference in seniority between protected and unprotected tranches, and the credit derivative contract contains a materiality threshold.
This amount is capped at the amount of capital the reporting party would be required to hold against the full value of the exposure or underlying expose, as appropriate.
This item represents a 50/50 capital adequacy deduction, therefore only report 50 per cent of the asset amount at this item. This amount is to be deducted from both Tier 1 and Tier 2 capital.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Guarantees And Credit Derivatives That Provide Materiality Threshold Fifty Per Cent Amount

This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of unrated securitisation credit exposures that are deductible from capital, plus all other applicable securitisation related amounts.
Other securitisation related amounts represent total securitisation-related amounts, other than those amounts classified as any of the following: - start-up and other establishment costs of a securitisation, where the costs have been capitalised. - gain-on-sale, including expected future income from a securitisation exposure that the reporting party reports as an on-balance sheet asset or profit, until irrevocably received; - funds provided by the reporting party to establish a spread, reserve or similar account, until the funds are irrevocably paid to the reporting party; - the difference between the book value and the amount received by the reporting party, where the originating reporting party transfers exposures to an SPV below their book value, unless it is written off in the reporting party's profit and loss (and capital) accounts; and - any other applicable amounts;
This item represents a 50/50 capital adequacy deduction, therefore only report 50 per cent of the asset amount at this item. This amount is to be deducted from both Tier 1 and Tier 2 capital.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
A securitisation represents a structure (a special purpose vehicle, or SPV) where the cash flows from a pool (of assets, or interests in assets) is used to service obligations to creditors (typically holders of debt securities) who fund the SPV.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Securitisation Related Items Other And Deductible Credit Exposures Fifty Percent Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of capitalised securitisation start-up costs.
The balance of any transaction costs and like items that are capitalised and deferred as an asset must be netted off against the balance of any income deferred as a liability relating to the products giving rise to the capitalised transaction costs (i.e. only deferred costs and income in particular product portfolios may be netted).
Any positive net balance of capitalised transaction costs must be reported as a positive figure. Any surplus of up-front fee income received over deferred costs may be reported as a negative figure provided the up-front fee income received satisfies the criteria set under Prudential Standard APS 111. Otherwise, report this item as zero.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Securitisation Start Up And Establishment Costs Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the shortfall in provisions for credit losses.
The reporting party must compare: (a) the total expected loss (EL) amount (before any tax effects) for non-defaulted Internal Ratings Based (IRB) exposures to the total eligible provisions (net of any associated DTA) for non-defaulted IRB exposures; and (b) the total EL amount (before any tax effects) for defaulted IRB exposures to the total eligible provisions (net of any associated DTA) for defaulted IRB exposures.
In both cases, where the EL amount is higher than the eligible provisions, 50% of the difference must be reported at this item.
This item represents a 50/50 capital adequacy deduction, therefore only report 50 per cent of the asset amount at this item. This amount is to be deducted from both Tier 1 and Tier 2 capital.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Shortfall Provisions For Credit Losses IRB Fifty Percent Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of reserves arising from the revaluation of the Eligible Component of Investments in Associates, Joint Ventures and non-consolidated Subsidiaries, and which can be classified as Upper Tier 2 capital.
Where a particular asset belongs to a class of assets for which the Asset Revaluation Reserve (ARR) are included in Upper Tier 2 capital and the asset has been identified as impaired and losses arise, the losses may be offset against any existing revaluations of the asset or class of revalued assets.
If the ARR is negative after adjustment for revaluations of assets included in the reserve, for losses due to impairment of assets covered by the reserve, and for any gains or losses on hedges offsetting revaluations of assets included in the reserve, report zero at this item.
This item is net of any fair value gains and losses, and any gains or losses on hedges offsetting revaluations included in reserves.
For the purposes of this item, do not include any ARR amounts that have been included as Capital Profit Reserves.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures arising from assets sold with recourse.
Assets sold with recourse are asset sales (to the extent that such assets are not included on-balance sheet) by an entity where the holder of the asset is entitled to 'put' the asset back to the entity within an agreed period or under certain prescribed circumstances (e.g. deterioration in the value or credit quality of the asset concerned).
Financial Risk Credit Assets Sold With Recourse Amount

Financial Risk Credit Claims On Corporate And Commercial Public Sector Entities Excluding Equity Amount
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claims on fixed assets under operating leases.
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Fixed Assets Under Operating Lease Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of Australian dollar claims on, or claims to the extent that they are guaranteed by or secured against securities issued by, the Australian Commonwealth Government.
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Or Secured Against Australian Commonwealth Government Australian Dollar Amount
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Or Secured Against Australian State Territory And Overseas Governments And Foreign Currency Claim Australian Commonwealth Government Amount
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Secured Against ADIs And Overseas Banks Excluding Equity Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claims on, or claims to the extent that they are guaranteed by, or secured against securities issued by, international banking agencies and multilateral regional development banks.
International banking agencies and multilateral regional development banks include, for example, the IMF, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Bank for International Settlements and the Asian Development Bank.
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Secured Against International Banking Agencies And Multilateral Regional Development Banks Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claims on, or claims to the extent that they are guaranteed by, or secured against securities issued by, local governments in Australia and non-commercial public sector entities in Australia and Overseas.
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Secured Against Local Government In Australia And Public Sector Entities Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claims on, or claims to the extent that they are guaranteed by, or secured against securities issued by, overseas central banks and foreign currency claims on the Reserve Bank of Australia.
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Secured Against Overseas Central Banks And RBA Foreign Currency Amount
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Private Sector Entities Excluding Equity Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of loans and all other on-balance sheet claims secured against eligible residential mortgages.
For the purposes of this item, the repayment of funds advanced must have been secured through an eligible residential mortgage to satisfy the debt in the case of default by the borrower, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Financial Risk Credit Claims Secured Against Eligible Residential Mortgages Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of loans and all other claims secured against non-standard eligible residential mortgages, and which are not insured with an acceptable Lenders Mortgage Insurer (LMI).
For the purposes of this item, lenders mortgage insurance must provide cover for all losses up to at least 40 percent of the higher of the original loan amount and outstanding loan amount. An acceptable LMI must meet APRA's requirements or those of the overseas host supervisor, as detailed in relevant prudential standards.
For the purposes of this item, the repayment of funds advanced must have been secured through a non-standard eligible residential mortgage to satisfy the debt in the case of default by the borrower, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
A non-standard eligible mortgage is an eligible mortgage that does not meet the requirements of a standard eligible mortgage, as detailed below.
A standard eligible mortgage is defined as a residential mortgage where the reporting party has: - prior to loan approval and as part of the loan origination and approval process, documented, assessed and verified the ability of the borrowers to meet their repayment obligation; - valued any residential property offered as security; and - established that any property offered as security for the loan is readily marketable. The reporting party must also revalue any property offered as security for such loans when it becomes aware of a material change in the market value of property in an area or region.
Financial Risk Credit Claims Secured Against Non Standard Eligible Residential Mortgages No Mortgage Insurance Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of loans and all other claims secured against non-standard eligible residential mortgages, and which are insured with an acceptable Lenders Mortgage Insurer (LMI).
For the purposes of this item, lenders mortgage insurance must provide cover for all losses up to at least 40 percent of the higher of the original loan amount and outstanding loan amount. An acceptable LMI must meet APRA's requirements or those of the overseas host supervisor, as detailed in relevant prudential standards.
For the purposes of this item, the repayment of funds advanced must have been secured through a non-standard eligible residential mortgage to satisfy the debt in the case of default by the borrower, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

The reporting party must also revalue any property offered as security for such loans when it becomes aware of a material change in the market value of property in an area or region.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the unsecured portion of any claim (other than a loan or claim secured against eligible residential mortgages) where the specific provisions against those claims represent less than 20 percent of the outstanding amount of the claim or impaired asset.
Financial Risk Credit Claims Unsecured Portion Where Specific Provision Less Than Twenty Percent Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the unsecured portion of any claim (other than a loan or claim secured against eligible residential mortgages) where the specific provisions against those claims represent no less than 20 percent of the outstanding amount of the claim or impaired asset.
Financial Risk Credit Claims Unsecured Portion Where Specific Provision No Less Than Twenty Percent Amount

This is the past due amount of credit card balances receivable by the reporting party as at the relevant date, i.e. the amount that has remained continuously outside contractual or approved arrangements.
A credit card is a card whose holder has been granted a revolving credit line up to a pre-arranged limit.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Card Past Due Amount
This is the value of all exposures of the reporting party that give rise to counterparty credit risk determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Amount

This is the outstanding balance of accounts at the relevant date classified by the reporting party as Category Four facilities, being overdrawn savings accounts and overdrawn limits on credit cards, overdrafts and line of credit advances.
Outstanding balances should be reported net of interest and other income not taken to profit, and net of any amounts written off. For overdraft facilities and revolving lines of credit, the outstanding balance is to be reported as the total amount of the facility outstanding, and not the amount that the facility exceeds the previously approved limit. For overdrawn savings accounts, the outstanding balance represents the debit balance of the account.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Category Four Facilities Amount

This is the number of accounts at the relevant date classified by the reporting party as Category Four facilities, being overdrawn savings accounts and overdrawn limits on credit cards, overdrafts and line of credit advances.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Category Four Facilities Count

This is the outstanding balance of accounts at the relevant date classified by the reporting party as Category One facilities, being: (a) an exposure that is secured by a registered first mortgage against a residential property and is insured by an eligible lenders mortgage insurer for 100 per cent of the outstanding balance; (b) an exposure that is secured by a registered first mortgage against a residential property, where the ratio of the outstanding balance, less the amount of mortgage insurance, to the valuation of the security is no more than 80 per cent (where the exposure is 6 months or more worth of payments past due, the valuation must be no older than 12 months); and (c) an exposure that is secured by a qualifying registered second mortgage where: (i) the ratio of the outstanding balances of the facilities secured by both first and second mortgages to the valuation of the residential property does not exceed 80 per cent, and the first mortgage cannot be extended without it being subordinated to the second mortgage; or (ii) where the ratio of the outstanding balances of the facilities secured by both first and second mortgages to the valuation of the residential property exceeds 80 per cent, and the first mortgage cannot be extended without it being subordinated to the second mortgage, and the outstanding balance is 100 per cent mortgage insured by an eligible lenders mortgage insurer.
Outstanding balances should be reported net of interest and other income not taken to profit, and net of any amounts written off. For overdraft facilities and revolving lines of credit, the outstanding balance is to be reported as the total amount of the facility outstanding, and not the amount that the facility exceeds the previously approved limit. For overdrawn savings accounts, the outstanding balance represents the debit balance of the account.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Category One Facilities Amount

This is the number of accounts at the relevant date classified by the reporting party as Category One facilities, being: (a) an exposure that is secured by a registered first mortgage against a residential property and is insured by an eligible lenders mortgage insurer for 100 per cent of the outstanding balance; (b) an exposure that is secured by a registered first mortgage against a residential property, where the ratio of the outstanding balance, less the amount of mortgage insurance, to the valuation of the security is no more than 80 per cent (where the exposure is 6 months or more worth of payments past due, the valuation must be no older than 12 months); and (c) an exposure that is secured by a qualifying registered second mortgage where: (i) the ratio of the outstanding balances of the facilities secured by both first and second mortgages to the valuation of the residential property does not exceed 80 per cent, and the first mortgage cannot be extended without it being subordinated to the second mortgage; or (ii) where the ratio of the outstanding balances of the facilities secured by both first and second mortgages to the valuation of the residential property exceeds 80 per cent, and the first mortgage cannot be extended without it being subordinated to the second mortgage, and the outstanding balance is 100 per cent mortgage insured by an eligible lenders mortgage insurer.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Category One Facilities Count

This is the outstanding balance of accounts at the relevant date that meet the provisioning requirements in accordance with the Prescribed Provisioning methodology outlined in the relevant prudential standards, but have not been classified by the reporting party as Category One, Two or Four facilities.
Outstanding balances should be reported net of interest and other income not taken to profit, and net of any amounts written off. For overdraft facilities and revolving lines of credit, the outstanding balance is to be reported as the total amount of the facility outstanding, and not the amount that the facility exceeds the previously approved limit. For overdrawn savings accounts, the outstanding balance represents the debit balance of the account.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Category Three Facilities Amount

This is the number of accounts at the relevant date that meet the provisioning requirements in accordance with the Prescribed Provisioning methodology outlined in the relevant prudential standards, but have not been classified by the reporting party as Category One, Two or Four facilities.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Category Three Facilities Count

This is the adjusted balance of accounts at the relevant date that meet the provisioning requirements in accordance with the Prescribed Provisioning methodology outlined in the relevant prudential standards, but have not been classified by the reporting party as Category One, Two or Four facilities.
The adjusted balance is the "Outstanding balance" (see below) offset by the amount of any collateral security held that satisfies the requirements of the relevant prudential standards, or APRA has agreed on an appropriate basis to ascribe value for security purposes.
Outstanding balances should be reported net of interest and other income not taken to profit, and net of any amounts written off. For overdraft facilities and revolving lines of credit, the outstanding balance is to be reported as the total amount of the facility outstanding, and not the amount that the facility exceeds the previously approved limit. For overdrawn savings accounts, the outstanding balance represents the debit balance of the account.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Category Three Facilities Adjusted Balance Amount

This is the outstanding balance of accounts at the relevant date classified by the reporting party as Category Two facilities, being an exposure that is secured by a registered first mortgage against a residential property, where the ratio of the outstanding balance, less the amount of mortgage insurance, to the valuation of the security is greater than 80 per cent but no more than 100 per cent (where the loan is 6 months or more worth of payments past due, the valuation must be no older than 12 months).
Outstanding balances should be reported net of interest and other income not taken to profit, and net of any amounts written off. For overdraft facilities and revolving lines of credit, the outstanding balance is to be reported as the total amount of the facility outstanding, and not the amount that the facility exceeds the previously approved limit. For overdrawn savings accounts, the outstanding balance represents the debit balance of the account. The balance outstanding should not be adjusted for any collateral value.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Category Two Facilities Amount

This is the number of accounts at the relevant date classified by the reporting party as Category Two facilities, being an exposure that is secured by a registered first mortgage against a residential property, where the ratio of the outstanding balance, less the amount of mortgage insurance, to the valuation of the security is greater than 80 per cent but no more than 100 per cent (where the loan is 6 months or more worth of payments past due, the valuation must be no older than 12 months).
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Category Two Facilities Count

Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Newly Impaired Amount

This is the value of all exposures of the reporting party that give rise to counterparty credit risk, determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards, where the estimates of future interest income are zero and no specific provision for impairment has been raised in respect of it.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Non Accrual Without Provisions Amount

This is the value of all exposures of the reporting party that give rise to counterparty credit risk, determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards, where the estimates of future interest income are zero; no specific provision for impairment has been raised in respect of it; and the reporting party is receiving full contractual payments.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Non Accrual Without Provisions Full Performance Amount

This is the amount of any income forgone during the relevant period from all exposures of the reporting party that give rise to counterparty credit risk, determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards, where the estimates of future interest income are zero; no specific provision for impairment has been raised in respect of it; and the reporting party is receiving full contractual payments.
Income forgone is the difference between what the reporting party would have received had the exposure performed as expected and that income actually received.
Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Non Accrual Without Provisions Full Performance Income Forgone Amount

This is the value of all exposures of the reporting party that give rise to counterparty credit risk, determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards, where: (a) the estimates of future interest income are not zero; (b) no specific provision for impairment has been raised in respect of it; and (c) the original contractual terms have been modified via a formal (written) agreement to provide for concessions of interest or principal for reasons related to the financial difficulties of the counterparty, rendering the facility non-commercial to the reporting party. In considering whether a facility is non-commercial, the reporting party needs to consider whether it would extend credit on similar terms and conditions to a new counterparty exhibiting similar risk characteristics.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of bills that have been endorsed under bill endorsement lines, but have not been accepted by, or have the prior endorsement of, another ADI. Report only bills that constitute direct credit substitutes.
A direct credit substitute is any irrevocable off-balance sheet obligation that carries the same credit risk as a direct extension of credit, such as an undertaking to make a payment to a third party in the event that a counterparty fails to meet a financial obligation, or an undertaking to a counterparty to acquire a potential claim on another party in the event of default by that party (i.e. the risk of loss depends on the creditworthiness of the counterparty or the party on that a potential claim is acquired).
Financial Risk Credit Direct Credit Substitutes Bill Endorsements Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of guarantees that constitute direct credit substitutes.
A guarantee is a pledge or agreement to be responsible for another party's debt or contractual performance if that other party does not pay or perform.
A direct credit substitute is any irrevocable off-balance sheet obligation that carries the same credit risk as a direct extension of credit, such as an undertaking to make a payment to a third party in the event that a counterparty fails to meet a financial obligation, or an undertaking to a counterparty to acquire a potential claim on another party in the event of default by that party (i.e. the risk of loss depends on the creditworthiness of the counterparty or the party on that a potential claim is acquired).
Financial Risk Credit Direct Credit Substitutes Guarantees Amount

A direct credit substitute is any irrevocable off-balance sheet obligation that carries the same credit risk as a direct extension of credit, such as an undertaking to make a payment to a third party in the event that a counterparty fails to meet a financial obligation, or an undertaking to a counterparty to acquire a potential claim on another party in the event of default by that party, constitutes a direct credit substitute (i.e. the risk of loss depends on the creditworthiness of the counterparty or the party on that a potential claim is acquired).

A direct credit substitute is any irrevocable off-balance sheet obligation that carries the same credit risk as a direct extension of credit, such as an undertaking to make a payment to a third party in the event that a counterparty fails to meet a financial obligation, or an undertaking to a counterparty to acquire a potential claim on another party in the event of default by that party (i.e. the risk of loss depends on the creditworthiness of the counterparty or the party on that a potential claim is acquired).

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of equity exposures.
Equity exposures are defined according to the economic substance of the instrument. This includes both direct and indirect ownership interests, whether voting or non-voting, in the assets and income of a commercial enterprise or financial institutions, and holdings of units in unit trusts.
Exclude equity securities: - which are deducted from capital for capital adequacy purposes; and - held in the reporting party's trading book, with the exception of those exposures that give rise to counterparty credit risk.
Short positions held in the banking book are permitted to offset long positions in the same individual equities provided that these instruments have been explicitly designated as hedges of specific equity holdings and that they have remaining maturities of at least one year.

This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average firm size of credit exposures.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Weighted average firm size = SIGMAi Salesi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi
Where: Salesi = the level of annual sales associated with the ith exposure. EADi = the exposure at default(EAD) associated with the ith exposure.
A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
Financial Risk Credit Exposures Weighted Average Firm Size Amount

This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average loss given default (LGD) of credit exposures.
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined risk in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Weighted average LGD = SIGMAi LGDi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi
Where: LGDi = the LGD associated with the ith exposure in the group. EADi = the EAD associated with the ith exposure in the group.
Loss given default (LGD) represents an entities economic loss upon the default of an obligor.
A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
Financial Risk Credit Exposures Weighted Average LGD Percent

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures arising from forward asset purchases deemed non-market-related off-balance sheet transactions..
A forward asset purchase is a commitment to purchase at a specified future date, and on pre-arranged terms, a loan, security or other asset from another entity, including written put options on specified assets with the character of a credit enhancement.
For the purposes of this item, non-market-related off-balance sheet forward asset purchases exclude:
- commitments where the entity purchasing the asset has an unequivocal right to substitute cash settlement in place of accepting delivery of the asset, and the price on settlement is calculated with reference to a general market price indicator (and not to the financial condition of any specific entity). This is deemed a market-related off-balance sheet transaction; and
- written put options expressed in terms of market rates for currencies or financial instruments bearing no credit risk. This is also deemed a market-related off-balance sheet transaction.
Financial Risk Credit Non Market Related Forward Asset Purchases Amount

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures arising from note issuance and revolving underwriting facilities.
Note issuance and revolving underwriting facilities are off-balance sheet arrangements whereby a borrower may draw down funds up to a prescribed limit over a predefined period by making repeated note issues to the market, and where, should the issue prove unable to be placed in the market, the unplaced amount is to be taken up or funds made available by the reporting entity being committed as an underwriter of the facility.

This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of other market-related off-balance sheet contracts (including credit derivatives), as required on form ARF_112_2A.
This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards. The reporting party may net claims and obligations with a counterparty that are covered by a legally binding eligible bilateral netting agreement.
This balancing item represents the value of total market-related off-balance sheet contracts (including credit derivatives) less those contracts which are classed as any of the following: - Interest rate contracts; - Foreign exchange contracts; - Equity contracts; or - Precious metal, Gold and other commodity contracts.
Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve: - Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or - Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value. The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).
Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Market Related Contracts Other ARF 112 2A Amount
